skill.name: gtars
skill.description: High-performance toolkit for genomic interval analysis in Rust with Python bindings. Use when working with genomic regions, BED files, coverage tracks, overlap detection, tokenization for ML models, or fragment analysis in computational genomics and machine learning applications.
skill.summary: Genomic interval analysis toolkit with overlap detection, coverage tracks, and ML tokenization
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Repository contains only markdown documentation. All 177 static findings are false positives triggered by markdown syntax and legitimate scientific computing documentation. No executable malicious code present.

content.user_title: Analyze genomic intervals with high-performance Rust toolkit
content.value_statement: Process genomic interval data for bioinformatics research. This toolkit provides fast overlap detection, coverage track generation, and tokenization for machine learning applications in computational genomics.
actual_capabilities: Detect overlaps between genomic regions using IGD index for fast queries
Generate coverage tracks from sequencing data in WIG, BigWig, and BedGraph formats
Tokenize genomic regions into discrete tokens for machine learning models
Manage reference genome sequences with refget protocol for sequence validation
Process single-cell ATAC-seq fragment files with barcode splitting and clustering
Export and import genomic data in BED, JSON, and NumPy array formats
limitations: Requires Rust/Cargo for CLI installation or Python bindings for API access
Large genomic files may require significant memory without mmap optimization
Does not provide variant calling or sequence alignment capabilities
Tokenization vocabularies are determined by input BED files, not pre-trained models

use_cases.title: Peak overlap analysis
use_cases.description: Identify overlapping regulatory elements between ChIP-seq peaks and gene promoters for variant annotation.

use_cases.title: Coverage track visualization
use_cases.description: Generate BigWig coverage tracks from ATAC-seq fragments for chromatin accessibility profiling.

use_cases.title: Genomic tokenization pipeline
use_cases.description: Convert genomic regions to tokens for training transformer models on genomic sequences.

prompt_templates.title: Basic overlap query
prompt_templates.prompt: Use gtars to build an IGD index from a BED file and query for overlaps with a specific genomic region.

prompt_templates.title: Coverage generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a BigWig coverage track from a fragments BED file using gtars uniwig with strand-specific parameters.

prompt_templates.title: ML preprocessing
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a TreeTokenizer from a training BED file and tokenize genomic coordinates for ML model input.

prompt_templates.title: Fragment analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Split a fragments TSV file by cell barcodes, then score each cluster against a reference dataset using gtars.

output_examples.input: Build an IGD index from promoters.bed and find which ChIP-seq peaks overlap with promoters
output: Built IGD index from promoters.bed (2456 regions)

best_practices: Use IGD indexes for repeated overlap queries to achieve O(log n) query performance
Enable memory-mapped mode (mmap=True) when working with very large BED files
Pre-sort regions before operations to improve merge and overlap performance
anti_patterns: Do not use gtars for variant calling or sequence alignment tasks
Avoid processing raw FASTQ files directly without first converting to BED format
Do not expect pre-trained tokenization models; vocabularies must be created from your data

faq.question: What file formats does gtars support?
faq.answer: Gtars supports BED files for genomic intervals, WIG/BigWig for coverage tracks, FASTA for reference genomes, and TSV for single-cell fragment files.

faq.question: How do I install the Python package?
faq.answer: Run uv pip install gtars or pip install gtars to install the Python bindings for programmatic access.

faq.question: What is the IGD index?
faq.answer: The Integrated Genome Database (IGD) is a specialized data structure for fast genomic interval queries with O(log n) lookup time.

faq.question: Can I use gtars with NumPy?
faq.answer: Yes, gtars provides seamless NumPy integration through starts_array(), ends_array(), and from_arrays() methods.

faq.question: How do I generate BigWig files?
faq.answer: Use the CLI command: gtars uniwig generate --input fragments.bed --output coverage.bw --format bigwig

faq.question: What is genomic tokenization?
faq.answer: Tokenization converts genomic coordinates into discrete integer tokens suitable for machine learning models like transformers.
